author: kkInkr
body:
Been using it for 4 months with both target day aggressive and Ultra-aggressive expert pies, they are growing by about 5 to 6% for those 4 months.

Then some of the self-made pies grow for 10% and luckily up to 16% since I put in some money for ENPH in January.

The hedgefund pies, Coatue Management grow 12% for those 4 months, and Tiger Global grow 5% for a month and 20 days.

Most can be put in and forget about it, haven't have worst case scenario yet. Worst case scenario can be the markets go into a correction where Dow Jones down about 3000 points for a month or a little more. I see my portfolio goes down 1 to 1.5% when overall market (Dow Jones) go down by 250 points on Friday.

Time in the market really > Timing the market most of the time, for earnings. Since if you invest early, you can see when is a good entry point.

If you want some ETFs LIT, FAN and TAN all seem to be good. Includes solar, wind and storage.

The limiting factor for green energy is the storage for when its night time or the wind is dead. Whoever leads the way in high capacity batteries is going to be HUGE.

author: dvdmovie1
body:
I think there are sectors within clean energy that are compelling and there are sectors (solar panels, for example; if you invested in TAN 10 years ago you've lost half your money) that are not. Just because something is green does not make it a good business. People were posting about "It's solar, so it's good, right?" about Sun Edison all the way into bankruptcy.

I do think that with ESG more money will flow towards sustainable investments, but I'd still be picky about sustainable investments like you would with any other sector.  Things like NEE and HASI I find interesting. SEDG/ENPH. I still don't want to own the FSLRs (which had another weak quarter the other day) of the world.

author: thecongocartel
body: sign up for vanguard or fidelity (online stock brokers) and in that account you’re going to want to buy a mutual fund which has all of the stocks in America in it in order to grow your money the safest way when you have that much time for your kids. Here’s Fidelity’s mutual fund for the entire American stock market. FZROX. Once you set that up you’re going to want to look up how to turn your DRIP on. This drip feature (dividend reinvestment plan) will take the dividends that FZROX will pay you every year and it will automatically reinvest them back into FZROX to buy more shares and create a snowball effect over time.

author: Cruian
body:
>Fidelity
Free trades on more things, but only ETFs not Vanguard funds. Leaves a couple hundred dollars of uninvested cash sometimes.
Can't automatically invest into an ETF at all. Theoretically supports automatic investment into mutual funds but the trades have steep fees.

Fidelity offers several index mutual funds that should have performance nearly identical to Vanguard's, in some cases, better. Fidelity's index mutual funds also almost always have lower expense ratios.

There are no fees for buying Fidelity mutual funds in a Fidelity account. In taxable accounts you may want Vanguard mutual funds or ETFs, but tax advantaged accounts it doesn't matter. Also the Vanguard patents expire in 2023, so that advantage may be short lived.

author: Cruian
body:
It sounded like it is a slow roll out over several weeks. Some people may already be getting it.

This isn't unique to Fidelity. Google does this with their OS upgrades, even for Nexus and Pixel devices, and I'm pretty sure they also do it in their app store.

author: DAB12AC
body:
I would open up a retail investment account of some kind.  This can be done with Fidelity, Charles Schwab, or some big institution like that.  I'd also bet that somebody at the bank you already use for checking/savings can guide you toward an investment account.

Am I correct in thinking you want your kids to start spending the money 20 years from now?  If so: 

Once you have the account set up, invest in an target date index fund for the year 2040 - something like this: [https://www.morningstar.com/funds/XNAS/VFORX/quote](https://www.morningstar.com/funds/XNAS/VFORX/quote).

Or is that how long you think you'll be funding the account, and they won't necessarily need the money until later?  If so, go with an S&P 500 index fund such as this: [https://www.morningstar.com/funds/XNAS/vfinx/quote](https://www.morningstar.com/funds/XNAS/vfinx/quote). 

It may be that you don't have enough buying power to get this exact fund, but that's ok.  Something similar will do just fine.  

After that, just keep pumping money into it.  Don't think about it.  The money will always be managed for you automatically in a way that is gradually more conservative as the years tick by.

**The main thing:** don't overthink the investment selection part of it. Saving the money in the first place is more than half the battle here.

author: TheStonedEconomist
body: Check out the fund FZROX (this is called a "ticker", it is the "name" of the fund). It is offered through Fidelity and is a zero cost fund. While most funds have a small fee (called an "expense" ratio, and expressed as a percentage), FZROX is free of fees. It is also a "total market fund" meaning it is designed to "track" (or increase/decrease with) the overall market. For long term investments, total market funds are common and generally recommended.

author: hexleythepatypus
body:
A couple questions for you:

1) Which target date fund are you holding in your 401k? One of the standard Fidelity Index ones? (e.g. I have a good bit of Fidelity’s 2055 Index FDEWX). I ask because Fidelity has different target date funds, some of which are much more expensive.

2) What funds are available in your 401k plan? Can you purchase iShares ETFs? Or is the fund selection pretty small?

I ask these things because while factor investing is pretty cool and technically more theoretically optimal when implemented properly, it’s hard to beat the behavioral benefits of automatically DCA-ing into a dead simple one fund portfolio that automatically rebalances for you.

If you’re really dying to get some flexibility though, then I think your plan of contributing up to the 401k match then maxing your Roth IRA (do Roth if you can) is good. But I would put leftover money after this back into the 401k and max it before looking at a taxable account. Utilize those tax advantages accounts as much as you can!

author: SirGlass
body:
Note I don't hate robinhood but I appreciate what they have done. Now nearly every major brokerage charges no commission . Schwab, Fidelity , Etrade , TD Ameridtrade and a whole slew of other brokerages.

Robinhood forced there hand, even if you think it sucks you can appreciate competition being good for the comsumer

author: Monstructs
body:
I have a Rollover IRA with 52k. I’m looking for advice on where I should move it to potentially the best products to put it in. 

My wife and I are in our mid/late 40’s. Combined we make right around $200k a year. We have about $95k in retirement accounts and about $10k in savings. We want to continue to grow our retirement savings, and still be able to travel.

We’re not against taking risks and playing the long game. Thought our single largest Rollover IRA has been fairly flat for the last 10 years (currently at $52k). It’s in a managed account with a financial advisory firm and in a fidelity account. The fees are $628 per month. I believe the fees are destroying my gains. It looks like the fund choices are producing, but the bottom line has felt flat (slightly upwards over the last 10 years). 

Out of that $95k, $18k is in a separate Fidelity account in a S&P 500 fund/product. And we have  5 shares of Amazon (totaling about $10k now) and a few shares of Visa & MasterCard (totaling $2.5k). 

Our home is valued at about $360k and we have about $250k left on the mortgage. Out two vehicles were both PreOwned, but not inexpensive and we owe about $20k on the 2016 Mini Cooper and $33k on the 2013 Porsche Cayenne. We have about $20k credit card debit we’ve been grinding down the CC debt over time. From as high as $45k or so, to $20k). 

My wife is very good with money. I am not. We money becomes an issue, I tend to look for a different employer. (My job is in pretty high demand and I have a good bit of experience).  

The two other upcoming expenses we foresee will be buying a preowned Airstream travel trailer and replacing our floors in our home. Other than that, it will be retirement savings. 

Any advice would be welcome.

author: Ken385
body:
Yes, but Fidelity doesn't offer access to the full session.  I believe they allow access at 7am et. (could be a bit earlier).  Only the SPX and VIX options trade in this early session.

You will need to use their Active Trader Pro software and pick extended hours when you place the order.

Just a heads up, many reps there do not know that this can be done.  I entered an order last week to confirm that it is still possible and it is.

author: SageCactus
body: Fidelity will let you do it.  You need to sign up for international trading in your account and then tell them Poland.

author: Crazy4nitro
body:
My son is 5. He watches me on my computer. He had questions as to what I do. What green and red means. 
So I took $200 in October and started him a UTMA account with Fidelity. 
Jan 1st I took my daily pocket change jug and deposited it. ($140)

He owns:

1-S&P 500 index

1-AMD

1-CocaCola 

5-Bed bath and beyond

$78 in cash

$340 invested and his account is worth $376 iirc

He asks almost daily to look and check on his companies. 

IG: Crazy4nitro 
He’s on there a few posts back.

author: Ken385
body:
Yes, the SPX and VIX options have a early session of trading between 3am and 915am et.  Liquidity isn't bad either.  The only retail broker that I know of that offers access to the whole session is IB, with Fidelity offering access to the latter part.  I have been trading this for some time and there are some opportunities every now and then.

Started about 5 years ago. Here is a Bloomberg article about it.

[https://www.bloomberg.com/professional/blog/response-overseas-demand-cboe-extends-vix-spx-options-trading-hours/](https://www.bloomberg.com/professional/blog/response-overseas-demand-cboe-extends-vix-spx-options-trading-hours/)

author: leadrain86
body:
Nah. Just do both.  Don’t blow your investment account(s) on trading. 

INVESTING AND TRADING ARE SEPARATE THINGS. 

You can buy and hold in one account and stock trade in another. 

NOT DOING BOTH AND KEEPING BOTH SEPARATE were OPs mistakes, not trading itself. 

Here’s the correct way: 

1. 401k investing (or something similar).  This is your first and foremost, put the money away, let Fidelity or whoever do their jobs, don’t touch it.  Monitor it, ask questions, maybe make some changes WITH your financial advisor.  Other than that, leave it alone. 

2.  Want to be like OP and never trade again, cuz you suck at it? Ok, open a second IRA, a Roth preferably, 100% ran by you, buy and hold the next Amazon, Apple, Netflix, etc. Woohoo, you’re a genius. 

3.  Not touching 1 or 2 whatsoever, day trade with separate funds that you’re ok with losing.  Have some type of limit...IE “if I lose 50k, I’m done because obviously I suck at this.”

author: jamesbondc
body: None. Why go with these if you can now trade commission free on big reputable brokerages like for example Fidelity, Td, Schwab or etc.

author: RVWood
body: I really love Schwab.  I have only used the majors, but between Vanguard, Fidelity and Schwab I think Schwab has the best overall user experience in terms of personal service and website usability.  In the end, they all have about the same offering though.

author: BooneCreek
body: This is possible on fidelity, which is what I use.

author: trader_dennis
body:
I was a former Lightspeed customer and when zero commissions were announced I tried fidelity. Active trader pro is impossible to day trade on. I could not submit an order in less than 15 seconds. 

I also found active trader pro lagged in quotes at the opening.  And my computer has 16gb sad and a 50 mb internet connection. 

I switched to Tda think or swim. Almost as good as Lightspeed and I can easily open a new stock and have an opening order submitted a within a second if I choose. The ladder is good to trade on. I submit multiple orders to layer into my position  I like to layer into post earnings trades so speed and quickness are requirements.

author: Calls-Only
body: Fidelity has an etf screener

author: thewestcoastavenger
body: I listen to Bloomberg on SiriusXM. I mostly read analyst reports through Fidelity. I've found that most financial reports are like NFL sideline reporters. They don't tell you anything you don't know and often you're thinking "no shit, everyone knows that".

author: Cruian
body:
I'm msot familiar with Fidelity. For FTEC for example at Fidelity: [https://screener.fidelity.com/ftgw/etf/snapshot/snapshot.jhtml?symbols=Ftec](https://screener.fidelity.com/ftgw/etf/snapshot/snapshot.jhtml?symbols=Ftec)

"Prospectus, Reports, Holdings & Index" near the top. Then in the popup window, the last tab "Daily Holdings Report" and open with PDF viewer of your choice.

author: fourteenstix
body:
Thanks for posting this. I’m trying to figure out the best way to get from where I’m at, which is almost all of my retirement holdings in a Fidelity 401k invested in a target retirement fund with limited options, to getting the small cap value exposure Ben recommends. 

Should I be in a target retirement fund at all?  Should I reduce my 401k contributions just to my company’s match and out the rest in my IRA for more flexibility, towards attaining the portfolio characteristics I’m after?

author: Nikk2019
body: Mine is invested in individual stocks.  It’s held through Fidelity.

author: iWOCuplikethis
body:
If this is for your children, fidelity allows custodial Roth IRAs. I also have my daughter’s in FZROX. You can have you kid retire a millionaire just putting $100 a month in. 

Once they can do chores you “pay” the $100 for washing your car or something because it’s supposed to be earned income and put it in their Roth. Say you start when your child is 5 and stop when they are 18, by the time they are 66 it will be worth over 3 million even if they don’t contribute anything more in their adulthood.

author: PapaCharlie9
body:
> just open a roth ira at fidelity or vanguard and contribute there.

This. Run, do not walk, away from American Funds as fast as you can.

Just go with Fidelity for both. Easiest option. You can buy Vanguard ETFs for free with a Fidelity IRA or brokerage account.

author: Napalm32
body: I like Fidelity's trading platform. It's very clean, minimalistic, relatively intuitive. I can't speak for any other platform but Fidelity. It does everything I need it to do and more. Would highly recommend.

author: Calivan
body: Ah... what? Fidelity has free trades, not just ETFs but also stock. Been that way for a while now.

author: jaysomething2
body: With current conditions like the viruses that are going is it a bad idea to invest in index funds? Do we expect the market to go down or these to continue to go up. I have money and FZROX at Fidelity and I’m wondering if I should move it to biomedical Stark’s instead.

body: Still on the waitlist since day one, so I moved my account to Fidelity. Already have my 401 and HSA through them, may as well consolidate.

author: Cruian
Iamnota_man
body: At Fidelity, pretty much the 1st statement.   Though in reality, every stock you buy could go to zero/bankrupt.....leveraged funds could do it quicker

author: Ugadawg7
body: Fidelity

author: JerseyFlashBoys
body: Update: Fidelity didn't issue me a 1099-B just a 1099-R so i did something wrong

author: hexleythepatypus
body:
A couple questions for you:

1) Which target date fund are you holding in your 401k? One of the standard Fidelity Index ones? (e.g. I have a good bit of Fidelity’s 2055 Index FDEWX). I ask because Fidelity has different target date funds, some of which are much more expensive.

2) What funds are available in your 401k plan? Can you purchase iShares ETFs? Or is the fund selection pretty small?

I ask these things because while factor investing is pretty cool and technically more theoretically optimal when implemented properly, it’s hard to beat the behavioral benefits of automatically DCA-ing into a dead simple one fund portfolio that automatically rebalances for you.

If you’re really dying to get some flexibility though, then I think your plan of contributing up to the 401k match then maxing your Roth IRA (do Roth if you can) is good. But I would put leftover money after this back into the 401k and max it before looking at a taxable account. Utilize those tax advantages accounts as much as you can!

author: SirGlass
body:
Note I don't hate robinhood but I appreciate what they have done. Now nearly every major brokerage charges no commission . Schwab, Fidelity , Etrade , TD Ameridtrade and a whole slew of other brokerages.

Robinhood forced there hand, even if you think it sucks you can appreciate competition being good for the comsumer

author: Monstructs
body:
I have a Rollover IRA with 52k. I’m looking for advice on where I should move it to potentially the best products to put it in. 

My wife and I are in our mid/late 40’s. Combined we make right around $200k a year. We have about $95k in retirement accounts and about $10k in savings. We want to continue to grow our retirement savings, and still be able to travel.

We’re not against taking risks and playing the long game. Thought our single largest Rollover IRA has been fairly flat for the last 10 years (currently at $52k). It’s in a managed account with a financial advisory firm and in a fidelity account. The fees are $628 per month. I believe the fees are destroying my gains. It looks like the fund choices are producing, but the bottom line has felt flat (slightly upwards over the last 10 years). 

Out of that $95k, $18k is in a separate Fidelity account in a S&P 500 fund/product. And we have  5 shares of Amazon (totaling about $10k now) and a few shares of Visa & MasterCard (totaling $2.5k). 

Our home is valued at about $360k and we have about $250k left on the mortgage. Out two vehicles were both PreOwned, but not inexpensive and we owe about $20k on the 2016 Mini Cooper and $33k on the 2013 Porsche Cayenne. We have about $20k credit card debit we’ve been grinding down the CC debt over time. From as high as $45k or so, to $20k). 

My wife is very good with money. I am not. We money becomes an issue, I tend to look for a different employer. (My job is in pretty high demand and I have a good bit of experience).  

The two other upcoming expenses we foresee will be buying a preowned Airstream travel trailer and replacing our floors in our home. Other than that, it will be retirement savings. 

Any advice would be welcome.
